column4: I am still having problems getting an ASUS Eee netbook to boot off of a usb memory stick ( a SanDisk Cruzer), and the 1st partition is bootable.  I set the bios 1st device to removable media, 2nd device to San Cruzer, and 3rd the internal Drive.  Its seems to be trying to boot off of it, but I still get windows.  Any ideas?
Did you ever boot from usb stick? Did it work?
Booting from USB stick is completely different than booting an internal harddrive.
use the usb-creator or UNetbootin (available for windows) for writing an ubuntu iso image to your usb stick.
Both programms take care of making the stick bootable.
The rest is to your BIOS -- different BIOSes use different methods, most work, but some fail.
thanks.  I have a normal install onto an 8gig stick, not the install image.
The normal grub installer won't boot your usb-drive installed ubuntu, sorry.
grub installer / grub bootloader
correct.  the usb stick has its own grub boot.
yes, but installing grub to the MBR of your usb-disk won't help due it will never be used by the BIOS.
I fear you only chance is to install grub somewhere on your harddisk so it gets started.
I install it with my hard drives physically disconnected so the usb's mbr would be set up
To be more verbose: When the BIOS boots an USB drive, it won't load the bootloader from the MBR.
A solution is to install grub and the grub files in the MBR of your internal harddisk and on a partition on this disk (the filessystem doesn't matter much).
Then grub could boot the system installed on your usb-disk without a fuss.
Å´hat was the problem if I may ask?
Hey, I got the full install mem stick to boot.  thanks for your help.
pretty much a bios setting.  there is a boot priority, and then a setting for which drive is the first drive.
That easy? Great!
it was the latter option that was needed. to set the san cruzer to be the 1st drive
and that the removable media had higher priority.  ;)
